SENT.plain: A 29-year-old female presented with an unusual case of Wallenberg's syndrome due to a dissecting aneurysm of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) manifesting as a sensation of heaviness in the occipital region and vertigo
Magnetic resonance imaging revealed infarction of the lateral aspect of the medulla oblongata
Digital subtraction angiography (DSA) revealed a spindle-shaped dilatation of irregular contour in the proximal portion of the left PICA
Pooling of contrast medium was noted in the venous phase but not double lumen sign
A suboccipital craniectomy confirmed these findings macroscopically
Blood flow meter monitoring before and after proximal clipping of the diseased vessel ensured the safety of the procedure
Follow-up DSA 3 years after surgery revealed no evidence of aneurysm recurrence
